links.slidetitle: Since Traditionalists are not usually very technologically savvy, instead of posting video lectures online, the best approach would be to work harder during the semester to make up for the lost time.

slidetranscripts.Text:
Welcome to the Generational Diversity Workshop Presentation!

Click the ‘next’ button on the bottom of the screen to begin.

Which Generation do you belong to?

We typically consider four generations of learners when talking about different learning styles and preferences. They are presented in the chart here.

Traditionalists are people who were born before 1946. They are about 70 years old or older now.

Baby Boomers are the next big group. They are people who were born between 1946 and 1964. These people are between 50 to 70 years old.

Generation Xers were born between 1965 and 1980, making them anywhere from 35 to 50 years old.

And finally we have Millennials. These people were born from 1981 to 2000. They are in their early 20s to mid-30s.

Click ‘next’ to continue.

Before we go into the details of the learning styles of each of these generations, I’d like to share a quote from Ken Bain.

“The best teachers have an intuitive understanding of human learning akin to the ideas that have been emerging from research… they use a much richer line of inquiry to design a class, lecture, discussion section… they begin with questions about student learning…”

So what does this mean? It means that understanding the way students learn can help us better design our classes and activities and we have to start from thinking about how our students learn.

Click ‘next’ to continue.

Here we have some guidelines for discussing the dimensions of diversity. Before we talk about what diversity is we have to set some ground rules.

The first one is that by acknowledging that learners of different ages have different wants and needs, we can use those preferences to our advantage to better reach and teach our students.

The next guideline is that we shouldn’t try to change everything about our classes. If you focus on a single aspect, it’s easier to change just one thing well instead of trying to change several different aspects of your pedagogy and not doing anything well.

Discussing diversity and how we can apply it to our classroom helps us increase our own understanding and awareness of the different generations, which in turn can lead to increased student success. If we don’t understand our students, we can’t help them reach their full potential.

And finally, it’s important to remember that we must exercise caution when generalizing on any one “type” of learner. There are some Baby Boomers who may be more comfortable with technology than some millennials and some Gen Xers may prefer more rigid structure similar to Traditionalists. It all depends on your students, which again, emphasizes how important it is to get to know your students and help them according to their needs.

Click ‘next’ to continue.

Let’s see what you know already.

Look at the chart and try to match up the qualities to the different generations. They’re in no particular order and some of the qualities may apply to more than one generation.

When you finish matching the characteristics to the generations, click ‘next’ to see the answers.

How did you do?

Traditionalists are usually “silent” learners. They don’t ask a lot of questions and usually accept what the teacher tells them. They also believe in fulfilling their duties before thinking about their personal enjoyment or leisure so they are very dedicated to doing their work and usually don’t slack off.

Baby Boomers want more independent learning experiences. They are more willing to try things on their own and are more likely to ask questions to learn. They also are curious about learning and want to learn just for the sake of learning, meaning they have more intrinsic motivation. They do want full attention so during class it’s important to give them opportunities to contribute. And similar to the Traditionalist, the Baby Boomer also has a sense of putting work and duty ahead of their own personal enjoyment.

Gen Xers don’t care how they learn as long as it’s efficient. They look for the best way to learn things and do that. They also want a more balanced lifestyle so they aren’t as willing to sacrifice their own pleasure and enjoyment for work. This is juxtaposed with their desire to be entrepreneurial since that requires a lot of work. In whatever they do they need to know how they will be able to use it and hate to have to be taught things they see as useless.

And finally we have the Millennials. They are the multi-taskers. They want to be doing several things at once so that desire may make them more likely to be bored in classes that don’t require them to do anything but listen. They want a blended lifestyle and the terms edutainment (education and entertainment) and workation (work and vacation) apply to them. They like to enjoy what they are doing and are willing to sacrifice a higher paying job for a job that is more enjoyable or that interests them. They are social learners and like to work actively with others to collaborate on learning experiences. They crave praise and want to know they are doing well and are focused on achieving goals both personal and professional.

Click ‘next’ to continue.

So what does the research say?

Life experience shapes the way individuals want to learn and be taught. In other words, we need to understand our learners prior knowledge and experience in order to understand how we can best help them learn.

And the time period in which a learner was born has a significant impact on the way individuals learn. So this topic of generational diversity is grounded in the research and it’s important to understand the differences between the generations.

Click ‘next’ to continue.

Now let’s apply what we’ve learned.

At the beginning of the Spring semester of 2016, there was a huge blizzard that caused the college to be closed for the first 2 weeks of the semester. This posed a real challenge to instructors who would then be required to cover the same amount of material with two weeks less.

Given the generational characteristics, what expectations would learners in the different generational groups have and what could you as an instructor do in a situation like this?

Click ‘next’ to answer some scenario-based questions on different approaches to this problem.

Thank you for participating in this presentation on generational diversity. I hope you’ve taken away at least one thing that you can apply to your classes.

For further questions or general inquiries about pedagogy, please contact Amy Chase Martin, the director of faculty development and instructional media here at HCC.

For questions specific to this presentation, you can contact Dr. Chris Helfrich or stop by the Faculty Lab in CL 232.

And don’t forget to check out our wiki where you can find resources related to this presentation as well as many other resources and topics regarding pedagogy, technology and student engagement.

Thank you for participating!
